Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Overall sentiment: Roughly half oppose mandatory real-name registration, about two in five support it, and the remainder express mixed or conditional views.
  • Main reasons for opposition:
  • Privacy and data security: strong concern about intrusive ID checks, data breaches, identity theft, and platforms/governments misusing or selling personal data.
  • Safety and chilling effects: risks to vulnerable users (e.g., survivors of abuse, marginalized groups, people in restrictive environments), potential doxxing, harassment, job repercussions, and reduced willingness to participate online.
  • Practicality and efficacy: skepticism that real-name policies would stop bad actors; worries about fake or stolen identities and uneven enforcement; preference for anonymity as a right.
  • Main reasons for support:
  • Accountability and safety: expectation that real identities would curb cyberbullying, harassment, scams, impersonation/catfishing, bots, and misinformation; some believe it would protect minors and aid investigations; perceived gains in authenticity and credibility.
  • Conditional or hybrid suggestions:
  • Platform-led verification rather than government mandates.
  • Back-end identity verification (KYC-style) with the option to display a pseudonym publicly.
  • Optional “verified” badges for those who choose to prove identity, especially public figures and businesses.
  • Emphasis on strong data protection, user choice, and non-coercive approaches.

In short, supporters emphasize accountability and reduced abuse, while opponents prioritize privacy, user safety, and practical concerns. A notable share favors middle-ground solutions that allow verification without forcing public disclosure of real names.

Summary B

Overall summary: - Sentiment skews against mandatory real-name registration. Approximately 60% oppose it, about 15% support it, and roughly 25% express mixed or conditional views. - Main reasons for opposition: privacy and data-security risks (intrusive ID checks, potential data sales, government access, hacks/leaks); personal safety concerns (doxxing, stalking, domestic abuse survivors, risks to marginalized groups); fear of professional or social repercussions for lawful speech; belief that anonymity enables healthy participation and support communities; doubts about enforceability and the possibility of forged identities; concern that tying identities could even worsen harassment by exposing targets. - Reasons for support: increased accountability and better behavior online; reduction in harassment, cyberbullying, scams, and catfishing; greater trust and credibility. - Conditional/compromise ideas: acceptable if required by platforms rather than governments; back-end verification with front-end pseudonyms, revealing identity only for serious violations; optional real-name use; recognition that benefits depend on strong data protection and that bad actors may still evade rules. - Overall, commenters value privacy and safety highly, favoring approaches that balance accountability with the ability to participate pseudonymously, rather than blanket real-name mandates.

[Question]

Do you support requiring real-name registration on social media platforms, where users must register and post under their real identity?

answer.text_box: I believe it's important for people to show their true identity. When you can avoid showing your real identity, people are more likely to be vicious and troll people online because they can hide behind a false persona. For that reason, people should be required to show their real identity so they can be called out by their real name.
